content.question:
<math alttext="N H 4 with a positive one charge, aqueous, plus, O H with a negative one charge, aqueous, react to produce, N H 3, aqueous, plus, H 2 O, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
When 0.20 <math alttext="Molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="N H 4 C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and 0.20 <math alttext="Molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are mixed, the reaction represented by the equation above occurs and a strong smell of ammonia, <math alttext="N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, is observed. Based on this information, which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: <math alttext="N H 4 with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> acts as a Brønsted-Lowry base.

<math alttext="N H 4 with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is a stronger acid than <math alttext="H 2 O, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is.

<math alttext="N H 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is a stronger base than <math alttext="O H with a negative one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is.

<math alttext="N H 4 with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C l with a negative one charge, aqueous " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> are a conjugate acid-base pair.

content.answer: <math alttext="N H 4 with a positive one charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is a stronger acid than <math alttext="H 2 O, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
